utterances: Yes.
Hi.
I would like to hear more about how McCain attempts to shore up the economy and what he intends to do to shore up consumer confidence in particular.
I'm at the rightful age of 30 but I do lean Republican and I have every intention of voting for him.
However, I think the most important thing in the end is going to be whether or not, you know, how we all do economically when making a decision.
What have you heard from him so far that encourages or discourages you?
Well, I think he's got a lot of experience in getting things done and also, like your previous caller had said, you know, working across the isle could get things approved.
And I'm excited about that and I think because he's, you know, arguably one of the most powerful senators in the U.S., I think he has the relationships there.
You had mentioned before with Senator Kennedy and some of the others to make - to push reform through and I'm really looking forward to that.
Ben, thanks very much for the call.
Thanks.
Let's see if we can go now to Dixon, and Dixon is with us from Rockford in Michigan.
Yes, hello.
Hi there.
You're on the air.
Go ahead, please.
Landis was asked today in the teleconference you mentioned what his chances are for being exonerated.

Yes, I'd like to hear Senator McCain return to straight talk and address the 10 trillion dollar federal debt and explain to us how we used to have pay to go and now we have tax cuts that we really can't afford.
Pay as you go is I think what you're referring to.
Pay as you go, whatever happened to that?
Whatever happened to the straight talk about pay as you go?
And how we can afford to have some 600 military bases all over the world and tax cuts, and pretend like we don't have a serious federal debt.
What scares you about the debt?
Well, I think everybody can afford to pay a little more in taxes - some of us weigh more than others - to address the debt we're leaving our grandchildren.
All right, Dixon.
Thanks very much for the call.
You're welcome.
And let's see if we'd get one last caller in and this is James.
James is with us from Wichita, Kansas.
Hello.
Hi.

I'd like to hear him talk about the trouble spots like China and its power over Korea, the vice president being in Georgia today, giving military aid, the fact that Russia's target might be the Ukraine.
And Africa, China wanting all of the resources in Africa and actually reaching out to South America.
We've got a real vegetable soup of problems I'd like him to address some of those world issues.
I think Vice President Cheney was talking about economic and humanitarian aid, not military aid, at least not at this juncture.
Well, we'll wait and see because we know how he did.
I don't know.
I think he did something in Iraq that was sort of his own personal agenda.
Just my opinion.
All right.
James, thanks very much for the call and are you going to be listening tonight?
Yes.
But I don't think I'll see Cheney.
I suspect not.
No. He is in Georgia tonight and we're not talking about Atlanta.
I think they were very smart to send him to the other side of the world.
Appreciate the phone call, James.
Bye.
And another reminder that you can listen to live coverage of NPR's coverage of the Republican National Convention on many of these public radio stations tonight.
And afterwards, a call-in show to give your reaction to what Senator McCain actually did have to say.
And that's again, you can listen also on npr.org.
I'm Neal Conan.
Ira Flatow is here tomorrow.
It's Talk of the Nation from NPR News in Washington.
Next month, athletes from around the world will meet in South Korea at the Winter Olympics.
A spot on an Olympic team is the culmination of years of hard work.
But what happens to an athlete's college education during all that training?
NPR's Elissa Nadworny went to the Olympic Training Center in Colorado Springs to see how they balance it all.
The world arena ice hock (ph) - this is sacred ground for figure skaters.
And the Olympics are just around the corner.
On the ice is Max Aaron.
He's a muscular former hockey player who's working on his finesse needed in the world of figure skating.
Max has been a U.S.
national champion but fell just short of going to Sochi in 2014.
This year, at 25, he's looking for a final shot at the Olympics.
He's had a shaky practice today, but his coach wants him to leave the ice on a positive note.
All right, Max, finish with a good rehearsal.
That's all you've got.
Max goes through his long program with Andrew Lloyd Webber's music from ""Phantom Of The Opera"" echoing across the rink.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""THE MUSIC OF THE NIGHT"")
(Singing) Let your mind start a journey through a strange new world...
There are just weeks left - crunch time.
But it's also crunch time in another arena for Max - professor Kuppenhiemer's lecture hall at the University of Colorado, Colorado Springs.
It's the week before final exams.
Hedge funds and aggressive investment strategies...
While he's been training, Max has been working towards his degree in finance.
That's changing the entire world of finance.
Think of it as a main course in quad Salchows, choreography and blade work with a side of hedge funds.
It's two different worlds.
You go in and you're in school, and no one knows who you are.
A typical day starts with an 8 a.m. finance class, then three hours at the rink plus warmup, strength conditioning, physical therapy and dance class.
Sometimes there's a night class thrown in, too.
Max says he's having the time of his life skating, but he knows that's not his whole story.
I hope I'm very successful in the sport of figure skating.
But it eventually ends.
And that's what I think a lot of athletes forget - is that once sport ends there's more to life.
Life doesn't just stop.
Leslie Klein sees this all the time.
Klein works for the U.S.
Olympic Committee helping athletes transition to life after sport.
They go into this retirement phase, you know, in their 20s or 30s.
And if they haven't gone to school, they have nothing to lean on to move onto a career in something beyond sport.
Beyond the hours and hours of training commitments, there are other hurdles, too - the big one, money.
A pair of ice skates alone costs nearly a thousand dollars.
My parents spent all my college money on skating, so (laughter) it's on me to get my education.
That's figure skater Mirai Nagasu.
She's from California, but she's taking advantage of a law in Colorado that gives in-state tuition to athletes training for the Olympics.
She's studying international business at the same college as Max Aaron.
The secret to success is coffee and caffeine.
She's hoping for a return to the Olympics.
She came in fourth in Vancouver in 2010 when she was just 16.
